title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Scepticism and the related Schools of philosophy. The special
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: method, on the contrary, is that by which we 6 speak against         6
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: each part of so-called philosophy. Let us then treat Scepticism
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: at first in the general way, beginning our delineation with the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: nomenclature of the Sceptical School.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER III.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Nomenclature of Scepticism._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The Sceptical School is also called the "Seeking School," from       7
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: its spirit of research and examination; the "Suspending School,"
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: from the condition of mind in which one is left after the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: search, in regard to the things that he has examined; and the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "Doubting School," either because, as some say, the Sceptics
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: doubt and are seeking in regard to everything, or because they
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: never know whether to deny or affirm. It is also called the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Pyrrhonean School, because Pyrrho appears to us the best
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: representative of Scepticism, and is more prominent than all who
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: before him occupied themselves with it.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER IV.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _What is Scepticism?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The [Greek: dynamis] of the Sceptical School is to place the         8
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: phenomenal in opposition to the intellectual "in any way
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: whatever," and thus through the equilibrium of the reasons and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things ([Greek: isostheneia ton logon]) opposed to each other,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to reach, first the state of suspension of judgment, [Greek:
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: epoche] and afterwards that of imperturbability, [Greek:
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ataraxia]. We do not use the word [Greek: dynamis] in any            9
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: unusual sense, but simply, meaning the force of the system. By
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the phenomenal, we understand the sensible, hence we place the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: intellectual in opposition to it. The phrase "in any way
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: whatever," may refer to the word [Greek: dynamis] in order that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we may understand that word in a simple sense as we said, or it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: may refer to the placing the phenomenal and intellectual in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: opposition. For we place these in opposition to each other in a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: variety of ways, the phenomenal to the phenomenal, and the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: intellectual to the intellectual, or reciprocally, and we say
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "in any way whatever," in order that all methods of opposition
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: may be included. Or "in any way whatever" may refer to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: phenomenal and the intellectual, so that we need not ask how
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: does the phenomenal appear, or how are the thoughts conceived,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but that we may understand these things in a simple sense. By
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "reasons opposed to each other," we do not by any means             10
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: understand that they deny or affirm anything, but simply that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: they offset each other. By equilibrium, we mean equality in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regard to trustworthiness and untrustworthiness, so that of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reasons that are placed in opposition to each other, one should
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not excel another in trustworthiness. [Greek: epoche] is a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: holding back of the opinion, in consequence of which we neither
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: deny nor affirm anything. [Greek: ataraxia] is repose and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: tranquillity of soul. We shall explain how [Greek: ataraxia]
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: accompanies [Greek: epoche] when we speak of the aim.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER V.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Sceptic._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: What is meant by a Pyrrhonean philosopher can be understood from    11
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the idea of the Sceptical School. He is a Pyrrhonean, namely,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: who identifies himself with this system.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER VI.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Origin of Scepticism._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Scepticism arose in the beginning from the hope of attaining        12
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: [Greek: ataraxia]; for men of the greatest talent were perplexed
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: by the contradiction of things, and being at a loss what to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: believe, began to question what things are true, and what false,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: hoping to attain [Greek: ataraxia] as a result of the decision.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The fundamental principle of the Sceptical system is especially
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this, namely, to oppose every argument by one of equal weight,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for it seems to us that in this way we finally reach the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: position where we have no dogmas.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER VII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _Does the Sceptic Dogmatise?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: We say that the Sceptic does not dogmatise. We do not say           13
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this, meaning by the word dogma the popular assent to certain
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things rather than others (for the Sceptic does assent to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: feelings that are a necessary result of sensation, as for
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: example, when he is warm or cold, he cannot say that he thinks
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he is not warm or cold), but we say this, meaning by dogma the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: acceptance of any opinion in regard to the unknown things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: investigated by science. For the Pyrrhonean assents to nothing
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that is unknown. Furthermore, he does not dogmatise even when       14
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he utters the Sceptical formulae in regard to things that are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: unknown, such as "Nothing more," or "I decide nothing," or any
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of the others about which we shall speak later. For the one who
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: dogmatises regards the thing about which he is said to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: dogmatise, as existing in itself; the Sceptic does not however
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regard these formulae as having an absolute existence, for he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: assumes that the saying "All is false," includes itself with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: other things as false, and likewise the saying "Nothing is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: true"; in the same way "Nothing more," states that together with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: other things it itself is nothing more, and cancels itself
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: therefore, as well as other things. We say the same also in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regard to the other Sceptical expressions. In short, if he who      15
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: dogmatises, assumes as existing in itself that about which he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: dogmatises, the Sceptic, on the contrary, expresses his sayings
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in such a way that they are understood to be themselves
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: included, and it cannot be said that he dogmatises in saying
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: these things. The principal thing in uttering these formulae is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that he says what appears to him, and communicates his own
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: feelings in an unprejudiced way, without asserting anything in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regard to external objects.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER VIII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _Is Scepticism a Sect?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: We respond in a similar way if we are asked whether                 16
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Scepticism is a sect or not. If the word sect is defined as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: meaning a body of persons who hold dogmas which are in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: conformity with each other, and also with phenomena, and dogma
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: means an assent to anything that is unknown, then we reply that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we have no sect. If, however, one means by sect, a school           17
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which follows a certain line of reasoning based on phenomena,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and that reasoning shows how it is possible to apparently live
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: rightly, not understanding "rightly" as referring to virtue
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: only, but in a broader sense; if, also, it leads one to be able
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to suspend the judgment, then we reply that we have a sect. For
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we follow a certain kind of reasoning which is based upon
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: phenomena, and which shows us how to live according to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: habits, laws, and teachings of the fatherland, and our own
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: feelings.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER IX.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _Does the Sceptic Study Natural Science?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: We reply similarly also to the question whether the Sceptic         18
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: should study natural science. For we do not study natural
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: science in order to express ourselves with confidence regarding
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: any of the dogmas that it teaches, but we take it up in order to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: be able to meet every argument by one of equal weight, and also
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for the sake of [Greek: ataraxia]. In the same way we study the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: logical and ethical part of so-called philosophy.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER X.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _Do the Sceptics deny Phenomena?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Those who say that the Sceptics deny phenomena appear to me to      19
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: be in ignorance of our teachings. For as we said before, we do
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not deny the sensations which we think we have, and which lead
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: us to assent involuntarily to them, and these are the phenomena.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: When, however, we ask whether the object is such as it appears
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to be, while we concede that it appears so and so, we question,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not the phenomenon, but in regard to that which is asserted of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the phenomenon, and that is different from doubting the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: phenomenon itself. For example, it appears to us that honey is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sweet. This we concede, for we experience sweetness through         20
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sensation. We doubt, however, whether it is sweet by reason of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: its essence, which is not a question of the phenomenon, but of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that which is asserted of the phenomenon. Should we, however,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: argue directly against the phenomena, it is not with the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: intention of denying their existence, but to show the rashness
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of the Dogmatics. For if reasoning is such a deceiver that it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: well nigh snatches away the phenomena from before your eyes, how
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: should we not distrust it in regard to things that are unknown,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: so as not to rashly follow it?
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XI.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Criterion of Scepticism._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: It is evident that we pay careful attention to phenomena from       21
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: what we say about the criterion of the Sceptical School. The
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: word criterion is used in two ways. First, it is understood as a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: proof of existence or non-existence, in regard to which we shall
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: speak in the opposing argument. Secondly, when it refers to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: action, meaning the criterion to which we give heed in life, in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: doing some things and refraining from doing others, and it is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: about this that we shall now speak. We say, consequently, that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the criterion of the Sceptical School is the phenomenon, and in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: calling it so, we mean the idea of it. It cannot be doubted,        22
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as it is based upon susceptibility and involuntary feeling.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Hence no one doubts, perhaps, that an object appears so and so,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but one questions if it is as it appears. Therefore, as we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: cannot be entirely inactive as regards the observances of daily
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: life, we live by giving heed to phenomena, and in an
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: unprejudiced way. But this observance of what pertains to the       23
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: daily life, appears to be of four different kinds. Sometimes it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is directed by the guidance of nature, sometimes by the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: necessity of the feelings, sometimes by the tradition of laws
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and of customs, and sometimes by the teaching of the arts. It is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: directed by the guidance of nature, for by nature we are            24
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: capable of sensation and thought; by the necessity of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: feelings, for hunger leads us to food, and thirst to drink; by
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the traditions of laws and customs, for according to them we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: consider piety a good in daily life, and impiety an evil; by the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: teaching of the arts, for we are not inactive in the arts we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: undertake. We say all these things, however, without expressing
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: a decided opinion.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _What is the aim of Scepticism?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: It follows naturally in order to treat of the aim of the            25
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Sceptical School. An aim is that for which as an end all things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are done or thought, itself depending on nothing, or in other
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: words, it is the ultimatum of things to be desired. We say,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: then, that the aim of the Sceptic is [Greek: ataraxia] in those
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things which pertain to the opinion, and moderation in the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things that life imposes. For as soon as he began to                26
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: philosophise he wished to discriminate between ideas, and to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: understand which are true and which are false, in order to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: attain [Greek: ataraxia]. He met, however, with contradictions
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of equal weight, and, being unable to judge, he withheld his
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: opinion; and while his judgment was in suspension [Greek:
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ataraxia] followed, as if by chance, in regard to matters of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: opinion. For he who is of the opinion that anything is either       27
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: good or bad by nature is always troubled, and when he does not
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: possess those things that seem to him good he thinks that he is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: tortured by the things which are by nature bad, and pursues
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: those that he thinks to be good. Having acquired them, however,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he falls into greater perturbation, because he is excited beyond
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reason and without measure from fear of a change, and he does
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: everything in his power to retain the things that seem to him
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: good. But he who is undecided, on the contrary, regarding           28
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things that are good and bad by nature, neither seeks nor avoids
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: anything eagerly, and is therefore in a state of [Greek:
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ataraxia]. For that which is related of Apelles the painter
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: happened to the Sceptic. It is said that as he was once painting
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: a horse he wished to represent the foam of his mouth in the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: picture, but he could not succeed in doing so, and he gave it up
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and threw the sponge at the picture with which he had wiped the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: colors from the painting. As soon, however, as it touched the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: picture it produced a good copy of the foam. The Sceptics
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: likewise hoped to gain [Greek: ataraxia] by forming judgments       29
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in regard to the anomaly between phenomena and the things of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thought, but they were unable to do this, and so they suspended
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: their judgment; and while their judgment was in suspension
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: [Greek: ataraxia] followed, as if by chance, as the shadow
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: follows a body. Nevertheless, we do not consider the Sceptic
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: wholly undisturbed, but he is disturbed by some things that are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: inevitable. We confess that sometimes he is cold and thirsty,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and that he suffers in such ways. But in these things even the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ignorant are beset in two ways, from the feelings themselves,       30
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and not less also from the fact that they think these conditions
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are bad by nature. The Sceptic, however, escapes more easily, as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he rejects the opinion that anything is in itself bad by nature.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Therefore we say that the aim of the Sceptic is [Greek:
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ataraxia] in matters of opinion, and moderation of feeling in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: those things that are inevitable. Some notable Sceptics have
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: added also suspension of judgment in investigation.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XIII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The General Method of Scepticism._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Since we have said that [Greek: ataraxia] follows the suspension    31
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of judgment in regard to everything, it behooves us to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: explain how the suspension of judgment takes place. Speaking in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: general it takes place through placing things in opposition to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: each other. We either place phenomena in opposition to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: phenomena, or the intellectual in opposition to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: intellectual, or reciprocally. For example, we place                32
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: phenomena in opposition to phenomena when we say that this tower
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears round from a distance but square near by; the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: intellectual in opposition to the intellectual, when to the one
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: who from the order of the heavens builds a tower of reasoning to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: prove that a providence exists, we oppose the fact that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: adversity often falls to the good and prosperity to the evil,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and that therefore we draw the conclusion that there is no
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: providence. The intellectual is placed in opposition to             33
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: phenomena, as when Anaxagoras opposed the fact that snow is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: white, by saying that snow is frozen water, and, as water is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: black, snow must also be black. Likewise we sometimes place the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: present in opposition to the present, similarly to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: above-mentioned cases, and sometimes also the present in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: opposition to the past or the future. As for example, when
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: someone proposes an argument to us that we cannot refute, we say
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to him, "Before the founder of the sect to which you belong         34
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: was born, the argument which you propose in accordance with it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: had not appeared as a valid argument, but was dormant in nature,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: so in the same way it is possible that its refutation also
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: exists in nature, but has not yet appeared to us, so that it is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not at all necessary for us to agree with an argument that now
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: seems to be strong." In order to make it clearer to us what         35
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we mean by these oppositions, I will proceed to give the Tropes
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ([Greek: tropoi]), through which the suspension of judgment is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: produced, without asserting anything about their meaning or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: their number, because they may be unsound, or there may be more
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: than I shall enumerate.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XIV.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Ten Tropes._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Certain Tropes were commonly handed down by the older Sceptics,     36
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: by means of which [Greek: epoche] seems to take place.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: They are ten in number, and are called synonymously [Greek:
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: logoi] and [Greek: tropoi]. They are these: The first is based
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: upon the differences in animals; the second upon the differences
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in men; the third upon the difference in the constitution of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: organs of sense; the fourth upon circumstances; the fifth upon
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: position, distance, and place; the sixth upon mixtures; the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: seventh upon the quantity and constitution of objects; the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: eighth upon relation; the ninth upon frequency or rarity of         37
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: occurences; the tenth upon systems, customs, laws, mythical
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: beliefs, and dogmatic opinions. We make this order ourselves.       38
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: These Tropes come under three general heads: the standpoint
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of the judge, the standpoint of the thing judged, and the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: standpoint of both together. Under the standpoint of the judge
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: come the first four, for the judge is either an animal, or a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: man, or a sense, and exists under certain circumstances. Under
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the standpoint of that which is judged, come the seventh and the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: tenth. Under the one composed of both together, come the fifth
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and the sixth, the eighth and the ninth. Again, these three
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: divisions are included under the Trope of relation, because         39
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that is the most general one; it includes the three special
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: divisions, and these in turn include the ten. We say these
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things in regard to their probable number, and we proceed in the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: following chapter to speak of their meaning.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE FIRST TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The first Trope, we said, is the one based upon the                 40
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: differences in animals, and according to this Trope, different
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals do not get the same ideas of the same objects through
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the senses. This we conclude from the different origin of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals, and also from the difference in the constitution of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: their bodies. In regard to the difference in origin, some
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals originate without mixture of the sexes, while others
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: originate through sexual intercourse. Of those which                41
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: originate without intercourse of the sexes, some come from fire,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as the little animals which appear in the chimneys, others from
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: stagnant water, as musquitoes, others from fermented wine, as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the stinging ants, others from the earth, others from the mud,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: like the frogs, others from slime, as the worms, others from
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: donkeys, as the beetles, others from cabbage, as caterpillars,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: others from fruit, as the gall insect from the wild figs, others
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: from putrified animals, as bees from bulls, and wasps from
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: horses. Again, of those originating from intercourse of the         42
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sexes, some come from animals of the same kind, as in most
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: cases, and others from those of different kinds, as mules.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Again, of animals in general, some are born alive, as men,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: others from eggs, as birds, and others are born a lump of flesh,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as bears. It is probable therefore, that the inequalities and       43
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: differences in origin cause great antipathies in the animals,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and the result is incompatibility, discord, and conflict between
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the sensations of the different animals. Again, the differences
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in the principal parts of the body, especially in those             44
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: fitted by nature to judge and to perceive, may cause the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: greatest differences in their ideas of objects, according to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: differences in the animals themselves. As for example, those who
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: have the jaundice call that yellow which appears to us white,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and those who have bloodshot eyes call it blood-red.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Accordingly, as some animals have yellow eyes, and others
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: blood-shot ones, and still others whitish ones, and others eyes
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of other colors, it is probable, I think, that they have a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different perception of colors. Furthermore, when we look
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: steadily at the sun for a long time, and then look down at a        45
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: book, the letters seem to us gold colored, and dance around. Now
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: some animals have by nature a lustre in their eyes, and these
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: emit a fine and sparkling light so that they see at night, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we may reasonably suppose that external things do not appear the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: same to them as to us. Jugglers by lightly rubbing the wick         46
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of the lamp with metal rust, or with the dark yellow fluid of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the sepia, make those who are present appear now copper-colored
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and now black, according to the amount of the mixture used; if
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this be so it is much more reasonable to suppose that because of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the mixture of different fluids in the eyes of animals, their
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ideas of objects would be different. Furthermore, when we           47
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: press the eye on the side, the figures, forms and sizes of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things seen appear elongated and narrow. It is therefore
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: probable that such animals as have the pupil oblique and long,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as goats, cats, and similar animals, have ideas different from
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: those of the animals which have a round pupil. Mirrors according
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to their different construction, sometimes show the external        48
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: object smaller than reality, as concave ones, and sometimes long
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and narrow, as the convex ones do; others show the head of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: one looking into it down, and the feet up. As some of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: vessels around the eye fall entirely outside the eye, on            49
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: account of their protuberance, while others are more sunken, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: still others are placed in an even surface, it is probable that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for this reason also the ideas vary, and dogs, fishes, lions,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: men, and grasshoppers do not see the same things, either of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: same size, or of similar form, but according to the impression
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: on the organ of sight of each animal respectively. The same
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thing is true in regard to the other senses; for how can it         50
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: be said that shell-fish, birds of prey, animals covered with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: spines, those with feathers and those with scales would be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: affected in the same way by the sense of touch? and how can the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sense of hearing perceive alike in animals which have the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: narrowest auditory passages, and in those that are furnished
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: with the widest, or in those with hairy ears and those with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: smooth ones? For we, even, hear differently when we partially
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: stop up the ears, from what we do when we use them naturally.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The sense of smell also varies according to differences in          51
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals, since even our sense of smell is affected when we have
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: taken cold and the phlegm is too abundant, and also when parts
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: around our head are flooded with too much blood, for we then
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: avoid odors that seem agreeable to others, and feel as if we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: were injured by them. Since also some of the animals are moist
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: by nature and full of secretions, and others are very full of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: blood, and still others have either yellow or black bile
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: prevalent and abundant, it is reasonable because of this to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: think that odorous things appear different to each one of them.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: And it is the same in regard to things of taste, as some            52
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals have the tongue rough and dry and others very moist. We
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: too, when we have a dry tongue in fever, think that whatever we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: take is gritty, bad tasting, or bitter; and this we experience
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: because of the varying degrees of the humors that are said to be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in us. Since, then, different animals have different organs for
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: taste, and a greater or less amount of the various humors, it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: can well be that they form different ideas of the same objects
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as regards their taste. For just as the same food on being          53
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: absorbed becomes in some places veins, in other places arteries,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and in other places bones, nerves, or other tissues, showing
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different power according to the difference of the parts
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: receiving it; just as the same water absorbed by the trees
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: becomes in some places bark, in other places branches, and in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: other places fruit, perhaps a fig or a pomegranate, or something
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: else; just as the breath of the musician, one and the same          54
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: when blown into the flute, becomes sometimes a high tone and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sometimes a low one, and the same pressure of the hand upon the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: lyre sometimes causes a deep tone and sometimes a high tone, so
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it is natural to suppose that external objects are regarded
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: differently according to the different constitution of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals which perceive them. We may see this more clearly in        55
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the things that are sought for and avoided by animals. For
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: example, myrrh appears very agreeable to men and intolerable to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: beetles and bees. Oil also, which is useful to men, destroys
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: wasps and bees if sprinkled on them; and sea-water, while it is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: unpleasant and poisonous to men if they drink it, is most
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: agreeable and sweet to fishes. Swine also prefer to wash in vile
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: filth rather than in pure clean water. Furthermore, some            56
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals eat grass and some eat herbs; some live in the woods,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: others eat seeds; some are carnivorous, and others lactivorous;
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: some enjoy putrified food, and others fresh food; some raw food
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and others that which is prepared by cooking; and in general
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that which is agreeable to some is disagreeable and fatal to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: others, and should be avoided by them. Thus hemlock makes the       57
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: quail fat, and henbane the hogs, and these, as it is known,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: enjoy eating lizards; deer also eat poisonous animals, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: swallows, the cantharidae. Moreover, ants and flying ants, when
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: swallowed by men, cause discomfort and colic; but the bear, on
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the contrary, whatever sickness he may have, becomes stronger by
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: devouring them. The viper is benumbed if one twig of the oak        58
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: touches it, as is also the bat by a leaf of the plane-tree. The
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: elephant flees before the ram, and the lion before the cock, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: seals from the rattling of beans that are being pounded, and the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: tiger from the sound of the drum. Many other examples could be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: given, but that we may not seem to dwell longer than is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: necessary on this subject, we conclude by saying that since the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: same things are pleasant to some and unpleasant to others, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the pleasure and displeasure depend on the ideas, it must be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that different animals have different ideas of objects. And
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: since the same things appear different according to the             59

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: difference in the animals, it will be possible for us to say how

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the external object appears to us, but as to how it is in

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: need of being judged than being ourselves able to judge. And

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: furthermore, we cannot give the preference to our own mental        60

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: representations over those of other animals, either without

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: evidence or with evidence, for besides the fact that perhaps
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: there is no evidence, as we shall show, the evidence so called

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to us, since the question is in regard to what is manifest to

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals, and we use as evidence that which is manifest to us who
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are animals, then it is to be questioned if it is true as it is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: manifest to us. It is absurd, however, to try to base the           61

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: questionable on the questionable, because the same thing is to

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: be believed and not to be believed, which is certainly
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills
