title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: objects.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _Have the So-called Irrational Animals Reason_?
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: We continue the comparison of the so-called irrational animals      62
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: with man, although it is needless to do so, for in truth we do
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not refuse to hold up to ridicule the conceited and bragging
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Dogmatics, after having given the practical arguments. Now most     63
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of our number were accustomed to compare all the irrational
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals together with man, but because the Dogmatics playing
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: upon words say that the comparison is unequal, we carry our
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ridicule farther, although it is most superfluous to do so, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: fix the discussion on one animal, as the dog, if it suits you,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which seems to be the most contemptible animal; for we shall
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: even then find that animals, about which we are speaking, are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not inferior to us in respect to the trustworthiness of their
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: perceptions. Now the Dogmatics grant that this animal is            64
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: superior to us in sense perception, for he perceives better
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: through smell than we, as by this sense he tracks wild animals
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that he cannot see, and he sees them quicker with his eyes than
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we do, and he perceives them more acutely by hearing. Let us
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: also consider reasoning, which is of two kinds, reasoning in        65
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thought and in speech. Let us look first to that of thought.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: This kind of reasoning, judging from the teachings of those
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Dogmatics who are now our greatest opponents, those of the Stoa,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: seems to fluctuate between the following things: the choice of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the familiar, and avoidance of the alien; the knowledge of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: arts that lead to this choice; and the comprehension of those
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: virtues that belong to the individual nature, as regards the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: feelings. The dog then, upon whom it was decided to fix the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: argument as an example, makes a choice of things suitable to        66
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: him, and avoids those that are harmful, for he hunts for food,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but draws back when the whip is lifted up; he possesses also an
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: art by which he procures the things that are suitable for him,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the art of hunting. He is not also without virtue; since the        67
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: true nature of justice is to give to every one according to his
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: merit, as the dog wags his tail to those who belong to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: family, and to those who behave well to him, guards them, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: keeps off strangers and evil doers, he is surely not without
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: justice. Now if he has this virtue, since the virtues follow        68
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: each other in turn, he has the other virtues also, which the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: wise men say, most men do not possess. We see the dog also brave
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in warding off attacks, and sagacious, as Homer testified when
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he represented Odysseus as unrecognised by all in his house, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: recognised only by Argos, because the dog was not deceived by
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the physical change in the man, and had not lost the [Greek:
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: phantasia kataleptike] which he proved that he had kept better
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: than the men had. But according to Chrysippus even, who most        69
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: attacked the irrational animals, the dog takes a part in the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: dialectic about which so much is said. At any rate, the man
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: above referred to said that the dog follows the fifth of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: several non-apodictic syllogisms, for when he comes to a meeting
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of three roads, after seeking the scent in the two roads,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: through which his prey has not passed, he presses forward
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: quickly in the third without scenting it. For the dog reasons in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this way, potentially said the man of olden time; the animal
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: passed through this, or this, or this; it was neither through
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this nor this, therefore it was through this. The dog also
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: understands his own sufferings and mitigates them. As soon as       70
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: a sharp stick is thrust into him, he sets out to remove it, by
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: rubbing his foot on the ground, as also with his teeth; and if
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ever he has a wound anywhere, for the reason that uncleansed
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: wounds are difficult to cure, and those that are cleansed are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: easily cured, he gently wipes off the collected matter; and         71
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he observes the Hippocratic advice exceedingly well, for since
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: quiet is a relief for the foot, if he has ever a wound in the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: foot, he lifts it up, and keeps it undisturbed as much as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: possible. When he is troubled by disturbing humours, he eats
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: grass, with which he vomits up that which was unfitting, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: recovers. Since therefore it has been shown that the animal         72
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that we fixed the argument upon for the sake of an example,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: chooses that which is suitable for him, and avoids what is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: harmful, and that he has an art by which he provides what is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: suitable, and that he comprehends his own sufferings and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: mitigates them, and that he is not without virtue, things in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which perfection of reasoning in thought consists, so according
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to this it would seem that the dog has reached perfection. It is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for this reason, it appears to me, that some philosophers have
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: honoured themselves with the name of this animal. In regard to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reasoning in speech, it is not necessary at present to bring        73
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the matter in question. For some of the Dogmatics, even, have
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: put this aside, as opposing the acquisition of virtue, for which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reason they practiced silence when studying. Besides, let it be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: supposed that a man is dumb, no one would say that he is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: consequently irrational. However, aside from this, we see after
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: all, that animals, about which we are speaking, do produce human
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sounds, as the jay and some others. Aside from this also, even
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: if we do not understand the sounds of the so-called irrational      74
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: irrational animals, it is not at all unlikely that they
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: converse, and that we do not understand their conversation. For
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: when we hear the language of foreigners, we do not understand
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but it all seems like one sound to us. Furthermore, we hear dogs
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: giving out one kind of sound when they are resisting someone,       75
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and another sound when they howl, and another when they are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: beaten, and a different kind when they wag their tails, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: generally speaking, if one examines into this, he will find a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: great difference in the sounds of this and other animals under
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different circumstances; so that in all likelihood, it may be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: said that the so-called irrational animals partake also in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: spoken language. If then, they are not inferior to men in the       76
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: accuracy of their perceptions, nor in reasoning in thought, nor
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in reasoning by speech, as it is superfluous to say, then they
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are not more untrustworthy than we are, it seems to me, in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regard to their ideas. Perhaps it would be possible to prove
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this, should we direct the argument to each of the irrational       77
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: animals in turn. As for example, who would not say that the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: birds are distinguished for shrewdness, and make use of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: articulate speech? for they not only know the present but the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: future, and this they augur to those that are able to understand
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it, audibly as well as in other ways. I have made this
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: comparison superfluously, as I pointed out above, as I think        78
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: I had sufficiently shown before, that we cannot consider our own
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ideas superior to those of the irrational animals. In short, if
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the irrational animals are not more untrustworthy than we in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regard to the judgment of their ideas, and the ideas are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different according to the difference in the animals, I shall be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: able to say how each object appears to me, but in regard to what
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it is by nature I shall be obliged to suspend my judgment.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE SECOND TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Such is the first Trope of [Greek: epoche]. The second, we said     79
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: above, is based upon the differences in men. For even if one
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: assent to the hypothesis that men are more trustworthy than the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: irrational animals, we shall find that doubt arises as soon as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we consider our own differences. For since man is said to be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: composed of two things, soul and body, we differ from each other
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in respect to both of these things; for example, as regards the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: body, we differ both in form and personal peculiarities. For the    80
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: body of a Scythian differs from the body of an Indian in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: form, the difference resulting, it is said, from the different
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: control of the humors. According to different control of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: humors, differences in ideas arise also, as we represented under
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the first Trope. For this reason there is certainly a great
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: difference among men in the choice and avoidance of external
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things. The Indians delight in different things from our own
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: people, and the enjoyment of different things is a sign that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different ideas are received of the external objects. We differ     81
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in personal peculiarities, as some digest beef better than
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the little fish from rocky places, and some are affected with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: purging by the weak wine of Lesbos. There was, they say, an old
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: woman in Attica who could drink thirty drachmas of hemlock
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: without danger, and Lysis took four drachmas of opium unhurt,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and Demophon, Alexander's table waiter, shivered when he was        82
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in the sun or in a hot bath, and felt warm in the shade;
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Athenagoras also, from Argos, did not suffer harm if stung by
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: scorpions and venomous spiders; the so-called Psylli were not
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: injured when bitten by snakes or by the aspis, and the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Tentyrites among the Egyptians are not harmed by the crocodiles
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: around them; those also of the Ethiopians who live on the           83
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Hydaspes river, opposite Meroe, eat scorpions and serpents, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: similar things without danger; Rufinus in Chalcis could drink
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: hellebore without vomiting or purging, and he enjoyed and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: digested it as something to which he was accustomed; Chrysermos,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the Herophilian, ran the risk of stomach-ache if he ever took       84
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: pepper, and Soterichus, the surgeon, was seized by purging if he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: perceived the odor of roasting shad; Andron, the Argive, was so
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: free from thirst that he could travel even through the waterless
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Libya without looking for a drink; Tiberius, the emperor, saw in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the dark, and Aristotle tells the story of a certain Thracian,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: who thought that he saw the figure of a man always going before
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: him as a guide. While therefore such a difference exists in men     85
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in regard to the body, and we must be satisfied with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: referring to a few only of the many examples given by the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Dogmatics, it is probable that men also differ from each other
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in respect to the soul itself, for the body is a kind of type of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the soul, as the physiognomical craft also shows. The best

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism

text: should please,

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE THIRD TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: While, however, the Dogmatics are conceited enough to think         90
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that they should be preferred to other men in the judgement of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: form a part of the disagreement; and if they give themselves
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the question before they begin the judgment, as they trust the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: judgment to themselves. Nevertheless, in order that we should       91
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reach the result of the suspension of judgment by limiting
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: differ from each other is evident. For example, paintings seem

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to have hollows and prominences to the sense of sight, but not
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears pleasant, but unpleasant to the eyes; therefore it is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: qualities than appear to us, but some of them do not affect us.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: have said about the food distributed in bodies, and the water

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regard to external objects.

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE FOURTH TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: In order to attain to [Greek: epoche] by fixing the argument on    100
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: give to one kind of fluid a power to change objects, and not

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: what kind it is, because the anomaly is not of a kind to be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: judged. For he who would pass judgment upon this is either in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: some one of the conditions mentioned above, or is in absolutely
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: no condition whatever; but to say that he is in no condition at
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: all, as, for example, that he is neither in health nor in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: illness, that he is neither moving nor quiet, that he is not of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: any age, and also that he is free from the other conditions, is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: wholly absurd. But if he judges the ideas while he is in any       113
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: condition whatever, he is a part of the contradiction, and,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: besides, he is no genuine critic of external objects, because he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is confused by the condition in which he finds himself.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Therefore neither can the one who is awake compare the ideas of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: those who are asleep with those who are awake, nor can he who is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in health compare the ideas of the sick with those of the well;
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for we believe more in the things that are present, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: affecting us at present, than in the things not present. In        114
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: another way, the anomaly in such ideas is impossible to be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: judged, for whoever prefers one idea to another, and one
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: condition to another, does this either without a criterion and a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: proof, or with a criterion and a proof; but he can do this
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: neither without them, for he would then be untrustworthy, nor
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: with them; for if he judges ideas, he judges them wholly by a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: criterion, and he will say that this criterion is either true or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: false. But if it is false, he will be untrustworthy; if, on        115
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the contrary, he says that it is true, he will say that the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: criterion is true either without proof or with proof. If without
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: proof, he will be untrustworthy; if he says that it is true with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: proof, it is certainly necessary that the proof be true, or he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: will be untrustworthy. Now will he say that the proof which he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: has accepted for the accrediting of the criterion is true,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: having judged it, or without having judged it? If he says so       116
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: without judging it, he will be untrustworthy; if he has judged
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it, it is evident that he will say that he has judged according
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to some criterion, and we must seek a proof for this criterion,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and for that proof a criterion. For the proof always needs a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: criterion to establish it, and the criterion needs a proof that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it may be shown to be true; and a proof can neither be sound
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: without a pre-existing criterion that is true, nor a criterion
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: true without a proof that is shown beforehand to be trustworthy.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: And so both the criterion and the proof are thrown into the        117
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _circulus in probando_, by which it is found that they are both
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of them untrustworthy, for as each looks for proof from the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: other, each is as untrustworthy as the other. Since then one
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: cannot prefer one idea to another, either without a proof and a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: criterion or with them, the ideas that differ according to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different conditions cannot be judged, so that the suspension of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: judgment in regard to the nature of external objects follows
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: through this Trope also.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE FIFTH TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The fifth Trope is that based upon position, distance, and         118
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: place, for, according to each of these, the same things appear
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different, as for example, the same arcade seen from either end
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears curtailed, but from the middle it looks symmetrical on
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: every side; and the same ship appears small and motionless from
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: afar, and large and in motion near by, and the same tower
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears round from a distance, but square near by. So much for
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: distance. Now in reference to place, we say that the light         119
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of the lamp appears dim in the sun, but bright in the dark; and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the same rudder appears broken in the sea, but straight out of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it; and the egg in the bird is soft, but in the air hard; and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the lyngurion is a fluid in the lynx, but is hard in the air;
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and the coral is soft in the sea, but hard in the air; and a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: tone of voice appears different produced by a syrinx, and by a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: flute, and different simply in the air. Also in reference to       120
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: position, the same picture leaned back appears smooth, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: leaned forward a little seems to have hollows and protuberances,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and the necks of doves appear different in color according to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the difference in inclination. Since then all phenomena are        121
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: seen in relation to place, distance, and position, each of which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: relation makes a great difference with the idea, as we have
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: mentioned, we shall be obliged by this Trope also to come to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: suspension of judgment. For he who wishes to give preference to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: certain ones of these ideas will attempt the impossible. For if    122
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he simply makes the decision without proof he will be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: untrustworthy. If, however, he wishes to make use of a proof,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: should he say that the proof is false, he contradicts himself,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but if he declares the proof to be true, proof of its proof will
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: be demanded of him, and another proof for that, which proof also
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: must be true, and so on to the _regressus in infinitum_. It is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: impossible, however, to present proofs _in infinitum_, so          123
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that one will not be able to prove that one idea is to be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: preferred to another. Since then one cannot either without proof
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: or with proof judge the ideas in question, the suspension of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: judgment results, and how each thing appears according to this
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: or that position, or this or that distance, or this or that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: place, we perhaps are able to say, but what it really is it is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: impossible to declare, for the reasons which we have mentioned.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE SIXTH TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The sixth Trope is the one based upon mixtures, according to       124
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which we conclude that since no object presents itself alone,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but always together with something else, it is perhaps possible
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to say of what nature the mixture is, of the thing itself, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of that with which it is seen, but of what sort the external
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: object really is we shall not be able to say. Now it is evident,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: I think, that nothing from without is known to us by itself, but
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: always with something else, and that because of this fact it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears different. The color of our skin, for example, is          125
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different seen in warm air from what it is in cold, and we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: could not say what our color really is, only what it is when
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: viewed under each of these conditions. The same sound appears
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different in rare air from what it is in dense, and aromas are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: more overpowering in the warm bath and in the sun than they are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in the cold air, and a body surrounded by water is light, but by
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: air heavy. Leaving aside, however, outer mixtures, our eyes        126
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: have inside of them coatings and humors. Since then visible
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things are not seen without these, they will not be accurately
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: comprehended, for it is the mixture that we perceive, and for
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this reason those who have the jaundice see everything yellow,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and those with bloodshot eyes bloody. Since the same sound
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears different in broad open places from what it does in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: narrow and winding ones, and different in pure air and in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: impure, it is probable that we do not perceive the tones
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: unmixed; for the ears have narrow winding passages filled with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: vaporous secretions, which it is said gather from places around
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the head. Since also there are substances present in the           127
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: nostrils and in the seat of the sense of taste, we perceive the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things smelled and the things tasted in connection with them,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and not unmixed. So that because of mixture the senses do not
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: perceive accurately what the external objects are. The intellect   128
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: even does not do this, chiefly because its guides, the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: senses, make mistakes, and perhaps it itself adds a certain
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: special mixture to those messages communicated by the senses;
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for in each place where the Dogmatics think that the ruling
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: faculty is situated, we see that certain humors are present,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: whether one would locate it in the region of the brain, in the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: region of the heart, or somewhere else. Since therefore
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: according to this Trope also, we see that we cannot say anything
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regarding the nature of external objects, we are obliged to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: suspend our judgment.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE SEVENTH TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The seventh Trope is the one which, as we said, is based           129
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: upon the quantity and constitution of objects, constitution
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: commonly meaning composition. And it is evident that we are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: obliged to suspend our judgment according to this Trope also in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regard to the nature of things. As for example, filings from the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: horn of the goat appear white when they are seen separately and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: without being put together; put together, however, in the form
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of a horn, they look black. And the parts of silver, the filings
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that is, by themselves appear black, but as a whole appear
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: white; and parts of the Taenarus stone look white when ground,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but in the whole stone appear yellow; grains of sand               130
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: scattered apart from each other appear to be rough, but put
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: together in a heap, they produce a soft feeling; hellebore taken
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: fine and downy, causes choking, but it no longer does so when
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: taken coarse; wine also taken moderately strengthens us, but       131
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: when taken in excess relaxes the body; food similarly, has a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different effect according to the quantity, at least, it often
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: disturbs the body when too much is taken, causing dyspepsia and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: discharge. We shall be able here also to say of what kind          132
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the cutting from the horn is, and what many cuttings put
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: together are, of what kind a filing of silver is, and what many
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of them put together are, of what kind the tiny Taenarus stone,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and what one composed of many small ones is, and in regard to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the grains of sand, and the hellebore, and the wine, and the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: food, what they are in relation, but no longer the nature of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thing by itself, because of the anomaly in the ideas which we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: have of things, according to the way in which they are put
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: together. In general it appears that useful things become          133
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: harmful when an intemperate use is made of them, and things that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: seem harmful when taken in excess, are not injurious in a small
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: quantity. What we see in the effect of medicines witnesses
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: especially to this fact, as an exact mixture of simple remedies
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: makes a compound which is helpful, but sometimes when a very
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: small inclination of the balance is overlooked, the medicine is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not only not helpful, but very harmful, and often poisonous. So    134
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the argument based upon the quantity and constitution of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: objects, puts in confusion the existence of external objects.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Therefore this Trope naturally leads us to suspend our judgment,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as we are not able to declare exactly the nature of external
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: objects.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE EIGHTH TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The eighth Trope is the one based upon relation, from which        135
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we conclude to suspend our judgment as to what things are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: absolutely, in their nature, since every thing is in relation to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: something else. And we must bear in mind that we use the word
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _is_ incorrectly, in place of _appears_, meaning to say, every
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thing _appears_ to be in relation. This is said, however, with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: two meanings: first, that every thing is in relation to the one
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: who judges, for the external object, _i.e._ the thing judged,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears to be in relation to the judge; the other way is that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: every thing is in relation to the things considered together
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: with it, as the relation of the right hand to the left. But we     136
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: came to the conclusion above, that every thing is in relation
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to something, as for example, to the one judging; each thing
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears in relation to this or that animal, and this or that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: man, and this or that sense, and in certain circumstances;
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as regards things considered together, also, each thing appears
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in relation to this or that mixture, and this or that Trope, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this or that composition, quantity and place. And in another way
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it is possible to conclude that every thing is in relation         137
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to something, as follows: does the being in difference differ
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: from the being in relation, or not? If it does not differ, then
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it is the same as relation; if it does differ, since every thing
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which differs is in some relation, for it is said to be in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: relation to that from which it differs, those things which are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in a difference are in a relation to something. Now according      138
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to the Dogmatics, some beings belong to the highest genera,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: others to the lowest species, and others to both genera
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and species at the same time; all of these are in relation to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: something, therefore every thing is in relation to something.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Furthermore, among things, some things are manifest, and others
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are hidden, as the Dogmatics themselves say, and the things that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE NINTH TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: In regard to the Trope based on the frequency and rarity of        141
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: events, which we call the ninth of the series, we give the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appearing at rare intervals, and at rare intervals setting, in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: those who experience it for the first time in the same manner
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as those who have become accustomed to it. How great the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: time, moves us more than if we are accustomed to seeing it. That
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and easily obtained seem by no means so. If, for example, we

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to be now valuable and now not so, we conclude that it may be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: them appears to be according to the frequency or rarity with
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which it occurs, but we are not able to say what each external

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: object is absolutely. Therefore, according to this Trope also,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we suspend our judgment regarding these things.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: THE TENTH TROPE.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The tenth Trope is the one principally connected with              145
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: morals, relating to schools, customs, laws, mythical beliefs,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and dogmatic opinions. Now a school is a choice of a manner of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: life, or of something held by one or many, as for example the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: school of Diogenes or the Laconians. A law is a written            146
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: contract among citizens, the transgressor of which is punished.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: A custom or habit, for there is no difference, is a common
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: acceptance of a certain thing by many, the deviator from which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is in no wise punished. For example, it is a law not to commit
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: adultery, and it is a custom with us [Greek: to me demosia
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: gynaiki mignusthai]. A mythical belief is a tradition              147
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regarding things which never took place, but were invented, as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: among others, the tales about Cronus, for many are led to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: believe them. A dogmatic opinion is the acceptance of something
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that seems to be established by a course of reasoning, or by
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: some other description. Now we place each of these things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sometimes in opposition to itself, and sometimes in opposition
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: offer strangers in sacrifice to Artemis, but with us it is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: opposition to a school when we oppose the school of Diogenes to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that of Aristippus, or that of the Laconians to that of the

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: belief, as by some traditions Jupiter is said to be the father

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of men and gods, and by others Oceanus, as we say--

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: We place dogmatic opinions in opposition to each other, when       151
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: opposition to a law, as according to the law it is not allowed     156

text: belief in opposition to a school when we say that, although the

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism

text: opinion when we say that the followers of Chrysippus hold          160

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills
