author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XV.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Five Tropes._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The later Sceptics, however, teach the following five Tropes       164
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of [Greek: epoche]: first, the one based upon contradiction;
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: second, the _regressus in infinitum_; third, relation; fourth,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the hypothetical; fifth, the _circulus in probando_. The one       165
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: based upon contradiction is the one from which we find, that in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reference to the thing put before us for investigation, a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: position has been developed which is impossible to be judged,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: either practically, or theoretically, and therefore, as we are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not able to either accept or reject anything, we end in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: suspending the judgment. The one based upon the _regressus         166
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in infinitum_ is that in which we say that the proof brought
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: forward for the thing set before us calls for another proof, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that one another, and so on to infinity, so that, not having
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: anything from which to begin the reasoning, the suspension of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: judgment follows. The one based upon relation, as we have          167
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: said before, is that one in which the object appears of this
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: kind or that kind, as related to the judge and to the things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regarded together with it, but we suspend our judgment as to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: what it is in reality. The one based upon hypothesis is            168
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: illustrated by the Dogmatics, when in the _regressus in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: infinitum_ they begin from something that they do not found on
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reason, but which they simply take for granted without proof.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The Trope, _circulus in probando_, arises when the thing           169
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which ought to prove the thing sought for, needs to be sustained
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: by the thing sought for, and as we are unable to take the one
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for the proof of the other, we suspend our judgment in regard to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: both. Now we shall briefly show that it is possible to refer
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: every thing under investigation to one or another of these
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Tropes, as follows: the thing before us is either sensible or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: intellectual; difference of opinion exists, however, as to what
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it is in itself, for some say that only the things of sense        170
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are true, others, only those belonging to the understanding, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: others say that some things of sense, and some of thought, are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: true. Now, will it be said that this difference of opinion can
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: be judged or cannot be judged? If it cannot be judged, then we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: have the result necessarily of suspension of judgment, because
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it is impossible to express opinion in regard to things about
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which a difference of opinion exists which cannot be judged. If
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it can be judged, then we ask how it is to be judged? For          171
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: example, the sensible, for we shall limit the argument first to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this--Is it to be judged by sensible or by intellectual
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: standards? For if it is to be judged by a sensible one, since we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are in doubt about the sensible, that will also need something
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: else to sustain it; and if that proof is also something
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sensible, something else will again be necessary to prove it,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and so on _in infinitum_. If, on the contrary, the sensible must
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: be judged by something intellectual, as there is disagreement      172
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in regard to the intellectual, this intellectual thing will
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: require also judgment and proof. Now, how is it to be proved?
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: If by something intellectual, it will likewise be thrown
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: into _infinitum_; if by something sensible, as the intellectual
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: has been taken for the proof of the sensible, and the sensible
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: has been taken for that of the intellectual, the _circulus in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: probando_ is introduced. If, however, in order to escape           173
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: from this, the one who is speaking to us expects us to take
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: something for granted which has not been proved, in order to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: prove what follows, the hypothetical Trope is introduced, which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: provides no way of escape. For if the one who makes the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: hypothesis is worthy of confidence, we should in every case be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: no less worthy of confidence in making a contrary hypothesis. If
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the one who makes the assumption assumes something true, he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: makes it suspicious by using it as a hypothesis, and not as an
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: established fact; if it is false, the foundation of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reasoning is unsound. If a hypothesis is any help towards a        174
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: trustworthy result, let the thing in question itself be assumed,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and not something else, by which, forsooth, one would establish
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the thing under discussion. If it is absurd to assume the thing
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: questioned, it is also absurd to assume that upon which it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: rests. That all things belonging to the senses are also in         175
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: relation to something else is evident, because they are in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: relation to those who perceive them. It is clear then, that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: whatever thing of sense is brought before us, it may be easily
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: referred to one of the five Tropes. And we come to a similar
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: conclusion in regard to intellectual things. For if it should be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: said that there is a difference of opinion regarding them which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: cannot be judged, it will be granted that we must suspend the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: judgment concerning it. In case the difference of opinion          176
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: can be judged, if it is judged through anything intellectual, we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: fall into the _regressus in infinitum_, and if through anything
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sensible into the _circulus in probando_; for, as the sensible
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is again subject to difference of opinion, and cannot be judged
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: by the sensible on account of the _regressus in infinitum_, it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: will have need of the intellectual, just as the intellectual has
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: need of the sensible. But he who accepts anything which is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: hypothetical again is absurd. Intellectual things stand also       177
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in relation, because the form in which they are expressed
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: depends on the mind of the thinker, and, if they were in reality
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: exactly as they are described, there would not have been any
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: difference of opinion about them. Therefore the intellectual
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: also is brought under the five Tropes, and consequently it is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: necessary to suspend the judgment altogether with regard to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: every thing that is brought before us. Such are the five Tropes
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: taught by the later Sceptics. They set them forth, not to throw
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: out the ten Tropes, but in order to put to shame the audacity of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the Dogmatics in a variety of ways, by these Tropes as well as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: by those.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XVI.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Two Tropes._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Two other Tropes of [Greek: epoche] are also taught. For as it     178
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears that everything that is comprehended is either
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: comprehended through itself or through something else, it is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thought that this fact introduces doubt in regard to all things.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: And that nothing can be understood through itself is evident, it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is said, from the disagreement which exists altogether among the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: physicists in regard to sensible and intellectual things. I
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: mean, of course, a disagreement which cannot be judged, as we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are not able to use a sensible or an intellectual criterion in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: judging it, for everything that we would take has a part in the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: disagreement, and is untrustworthy. Nor is it conceded that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: anything can be comprehended through something else; for if        179
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: a thing is comprehended through something, that must always in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: turn be comprehended through something else, and the _regressus
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in infinitum_ or the _circulus in probando_ follow. If, on the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: contrary, a thing is comprehended through something that one
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: wishes to use as if it had been comprehended through itself,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this is opposed to the fact that nothing can be comprehended
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: through itself, according to what we have said. We do not know
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: how that which contradicts itself can be comprehended, either
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: through itself or through something else, as no criterion of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: truth or of comprehension appears, and signs without proof would
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: be rejected, as we shall see in the next book. So much will
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: suffice for the present about suspension of judgment.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XVII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _What are the Tropes for the overturning of Aetiology?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: In the same manner as we teach the Tropes of [Greek: epoche],      180
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: some set forth Tropes through which we oppose the Dogmatics,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: by expressing doubt in regard to the aetiology of which they are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: especially proud. So Aenesidemus teaches eight Tropes, by which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he thinks that he can prove all the dogmatic aetiology useless.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The first of these Tropes, he said, relates to the character       181
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of aetiology in general, which does not give incontestable
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: testimony in regard to phenomena, because it treats of unseen
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things. The second Trope states that although abundant resources
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: exist by which to investigate the cause of a thing in question,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: some Dogmatics investigate it in one way only. The third Trope     182
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: states that the Dogmatics assign causes which do not show
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: any order for things which have taken place in an orderly
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: manner. The fourth Trope states that the Dogmatics, accepting
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: phenomena as they take place, think that they also understand
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: how unseen things take place, although perhaps the unseen things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: have taken place in the same way as the phenomena, and perhaps
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in some other way peculiar to themselves. The fifth Trope states   183
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that they all, so to speak, assign causes according to their
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: own hypotheses about the elements, but not according to any
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: commonly accepted methods. The sixth states that they often
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: explain things investigated according to their own hypotheses,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but ignore opposing hypotheses which have equal probability. The
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: seventh states that they often give reasons for things that        184
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not only conflict with phenomena, but also with their own
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: hypotheses. The eighth states that although that which seems
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: manifest, and that which is to be investigated, are often
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: equally inscrutable, they build up a theory from the one about
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the other, although both are equally inscrutable. It is not
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: impossible, Aenesidemus said also, that some Dogmatics             185
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: should fail in their theories of causality from other
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: combinations of reasons deducible from the Tropes given above.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Perhaps also the five Tropes of [Greek: epoche] are sufficient
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to refute aetiology, for he who proposes a cause will propose
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: one which is either in harmony with all the sects of philosophy,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: with Scepticism, and with phenomena, or one that is not.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Perhaps, however, it is not possible that a cause should be in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: harmony with them, for phenomena and unknown things altogether
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: disagree with each other. If it is not in harmony with them, the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reason of this will also be demanded of the one who proposed       186
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: it; and if he accepts a phenomenon as the cause of a phenomenon,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: or something unknown as the cause of the unknown, he will be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thrown into the _regressus in infinitum_; if he uses one cause
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to account for another one, into the _circulus in probando_; but
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: if he stops anywhere, he will either say that the cause that he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: proposes holds good so far as regards the things that have been
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: said, and introduce relation, abolishing an absolute standpoint;
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: or if he accepts anything by hypothesis, he will be attacked by
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: us. Therefore it is perhaps possible to put the temerity of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Dogmatics to shame in aetiology by these Tropes.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XVIII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Sceptical Formulae._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: When we use any one of these Tropes, or the Tropes of              187
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: [Greek: epoche], we employ with them certain formulae which show
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the Sceptical method and our own feeling, as for instance, the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sayings, "No more," "One must determine nothing," and certain
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: others. It is fitting therefore to treat of these in this place.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Let us begin with "No more."
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XIX.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Formula "No more."_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: We sometimes express this as I have given it, and sometimes        188
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thus, "Nothing more." For we do not accept the "No more," as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: some understand it, for the examination of the special, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "Nothing more" for that of the general, but we use "No more" and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "Nothing more" without any difference, and we shall at present
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: treat of them as one and the same expression. Now this formula
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is defective, for as when we say a double one we really mean a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: double garment, and when we say a broad one we really mean a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: broad road; so when we say "No more" we mean really no more than
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this, or in every way the same. But some of the Sceptics use       189
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: instead of the interrogation "No?" the interrogation "What, this
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: rather than this?" using the word "what" in the sense of "what
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is the reason," so that the formula means, "What is the reason
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for this rather than for this?" It is a customary thing,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: however, to use an interrogation instead of a statement, as "Who
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of the mortals does not know the wife of Jupiter?" and also to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: use a statement instead of an interrogation, as "I seek where
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Dion dwells," and "I ask why one should admire a poet." The word
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "what" is also used instead of "what for" by Menander--"(For)
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: what did I remain behind?" The formula "Not more this than this"
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: expresses our own condition of mind, and signifies that            190
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: because of the equality of the things that are opposed to each
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: other we finally attain to a state of equilibrium of soul. We
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: mean by equality that equality which appears to us as probable,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: by things placed in opposition to each other we mean simply
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things which conflict with each other, and by a state of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: equilibrium we mean a state in which we do not assent to one
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thing more than to another. Even if the formula "Nothing           191
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: more" seems to express assent or denial, we do not use it so,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but we use it loosely, and not with accuracy, either instead of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: an interrogation or instead of saying, "I do not know to which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of these I would assent, and to which I would not." What lies
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: before us is to express what appears to us, but we are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: indifferent to the words by which we express it. This must be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: understood, however, that we use the formula "Nothing more"
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: without affirming in regard to it that it is wholly sure and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: true, but we present it as it appears to us.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XX.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _Aphasia._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: We explain Aphasia as follows: The word [Greek: phasis] is used    192
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in two ways, having a general and a special signification.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: According to the general signification, it expresses affirmation
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: or negation, as "It is day" or "It is not day"; according to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: special signification, it expresses an affirmation only, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: negations are not called [Greek: phaseis]. Now Aphasia is the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: opposite of [Greek: phasis] in its general signification, which,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as we said, comprises both affirmation and negation. It follows
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that Aphasia is a condition of mind, according to which we say
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that we neither affirm nor deny anything. It is evident from
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this that we do not understand by Aphasia something that           193
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: inevitably results from the nature of things, but we mean that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we now find ourselves in the condition of mind expressed by it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in regard to the things that are under investigation. It is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: necessary to remember that we do not say that we affirm or deny
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: any of those things that are dogmatically stated in regard to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the unknown, for we yield assent only to those things which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: affect our feelings and oblige us to assent to them.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXI.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _"Perhaps," and "It is possible," and "It may be."_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The formulae "Perhaps," and "Perhaps not," and "It is              194
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: possible," and "It is not possible," and "It may be," and "It
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: [Greek: epoche] _or the Suspension of Judgment._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: When I say that I suspend my judgment, I mean that I cannot        196
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: say which of those things presented should be believed, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXIII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Formula "I determine Nothing."_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: In regard to the formula "I determine nothing," we say the         197
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: following: By "determine" we mean, not simply to speak, but to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: give assent to an affirmation with regard to some unknown thing.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: For it will soon be found that the Sceptic determines nothing,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not even the formula "I determine nothing," for this formula is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not a dogmatic opinion, that is an assent to something unknown,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but an expression declaring what our condition of mind is. When,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for example, the Sceptic says, "I determine nothing," he means
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this: "According to my present feeling I can assert or deny
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: nothing dogmatically regarding the things under investigation,"
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and in saying this he expresses what appears to him in reference
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to the things under discussion. He does not express himself
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: positively, but he states what he feels.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXIV.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Formula "Every thing is Undetermined."_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The expression "Indetermination" furthermore shows a state         198
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of mind in which we neither deny nor affirm positively anything
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regarding things that are investigated in a dogmatic way, that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is the things that are unknown. When then the Sceptic says
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "Every thing is undetermined," he uses "is undetermined," in the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sense of "it appears undetermined to him." The words "every
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: thing" do not mean all existences, but those that he has
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: examined of the unknown things that are investigated by the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Dogmatists. By "undetermined," he means that there is no
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: preference in the things that are placed in opposition to each
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: other, or that they simply conflict with each other in respect
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to trustworthiness or untrustworthiness. And as the one who        199
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: says "I am walking" really means "It is I that am walking," so
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he who says "Every thing is undetermined" means at the same
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: time, according to our teachings, "as far as I am concerned," or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "as it appears to me," as if he were saying "As far as I have
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: examined the things that are under investigation in a dogmatic
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: manner, it appears to me that no one of them excels the one
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which conflicts with it in trustworthiness or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: untrustworthiness."
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXV.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Formula "Every thing is Incomprehensible."_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: We treat the formula "Every thing is incomprehensible" in          200
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the same way. For "every thing" we interpret in the same way as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: above, and we supply the words "to me" so that what we say is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this: "As far as I have inspected the unknown things which are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: dogmatically examined, it appears to me that every thing is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: incomprehensible." This is not, however, to affirm that the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things which are examined by the Dogmatists are of such a nature
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as to be necessarily incomprehensible, but one expresses his own
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: feeling in saying "I see that I have not thus far comprehended
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: any of those things because of the equilibrium of the things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that are placed in opposition to each other." Whence it seems to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: me that every thing that has been brought forward to dispute our
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: formulae has fallen wide of the mark.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXVI.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: understand."_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The formulae "I do not comprehend" and "I do not understand"       201
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: show a condition of mind in which the Sceptic stands aloof for
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the present from asserting or denying anything in regard to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: unknown things under investigation, as is evident from what we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: said before about the other formulae.

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXVII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _The Formula "To place an equal Statement in opposition
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to every Statement."_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Furthermore, when we say "Every statement may have an equal        202
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: statement placed in opposition to it," by "every," we mean all
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the statements that we have examined; we do not use the word
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "statement" simply, but for a statement which seeks to prove
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: something dogmatically about things that are unknown, and not at
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: all one that shows a process of reasoning from premises and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: conclusions, but something which is put together in any sort of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: way. We use the word "equal" in reference to trustworthiness or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: untrustworthiness. "Is placed in opposition" we use instead of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the common expression "to conflict with," and we supply "as it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appears to me." When therefore one says, "It seems to me           203
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that every statement which I have examined, which proves
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: something dogmatically, may have another statement placed in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: opposition to it which also proves something dogmatically, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: which is equal to it in trustworthiness and untrustworthiness,"
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this is not asserted dogmatically, but is an expression of human
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: feeling as it appears to the one who feels it. Some Sceptics       204
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: express the formula as follows: "Every statement should have an
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: equal one placed in opposition to it," demanding it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: authoritatively thus: "Let us place in opposition to every
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: statement that proves something dogmatically another conflicting
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: statement which also seeks to prove something dogmatically, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is equal to it in trustworthiness and untrustworthiness."
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Naturally this is directed to the Sceptics, but the infinitive
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: should be used instead of the imperative, that is, "to oppose"
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: instead of "let us oppose." This formula is recommended to the     205
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Sceptic, lest he should be deceived by the Dogmatists and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: give up his investigations, and rashly fail of the [Greek:
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ataraxia] which is thought to accompany [Greek: epoche] in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: regard to everything, as we have explained above.

author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXVIII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _General Observations on the Formulae of the Sceptics._
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: We have treated of a sufficient number of these formulae for       206
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: an outline, especially since what we have said about those
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: mentioned applies also to others that we have omitted. In regard
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to all the Sceptical formulae, it must be understood in advance
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that we do not affirm them to be absolutely true, because we say
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that they can even refute themselves, since they are themselves
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: included in those things to which they refer, just as cathartic
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: medicines not only purge the body of humors, but carry off
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: themselves with the humors. We say then that we use these          207
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: formulae, not as literally making known the things for which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: they are used, but loosely, and if one wishes, inaccurately. It
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is not fitting for the Sceptic to dispute about words,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: especially as it contributes to our purpose to say that these
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: formulae have no absolute meaning; their meaning is a relative
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: one, that is, relative to the Sceptics. Besides, it is to be       208
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: remembered that we do not say them about all things in general,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but about the unknown, and things that are dogmatically
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: investigated, and that we say what appears to us, and that we do
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not express ourselves decidedly about the nature of external
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: objects. By this means I think that every sophism brought
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: against the Sceptical formulae can be overturned. We have now      209
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: shown the character of Scepticism by examining its idea, its
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: parts, its criterion and aim, and also the Tropes of [Greek:
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: epoche], and by treating of the Sceptical formulae. We think it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: therefore appropriate to enter briefly into the distinction
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: between Scepticism and the nearly related schools of philosophy
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in order to more clearly understand the Sceptical School. We
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: will begin with the philosophy of Heraclitus.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXIX.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _In what does the Sceptical School differ from the Philosophy
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of Heraclitus?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Now that this school differs from ours is evident, for             210
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Heraclitus expresses himself about many unknown things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: dogmatically, which we do not, as has been said. Aenesidemus and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: his followers said that the Sceptical School is the way to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: philosophy of Heraclitus. They gave as a reason for this that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the statement that contradictory predicates appear to be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: applicable to the same thing, leads the way to the statement
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that contradictory predicates are in reality applicable to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: same thing; and as the Sceptics say that contradictory
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: predicates appear to be applicable to the same thing, the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Heraclitans proceed from this to the doctrine that such
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: predicates are in reality applicable. We reply to this that the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: statement that contradictory predicates appear to be applicable
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to the same thing is not a dogma of the Sceptics, but is a fact
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that presents itself not only to the Sceptics, but to other
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: philosophers, and to all men. No one, for instance, would          211
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: venture to say that honey does not taste sweet to those in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: health, and bitter to those who have the jaundice, so that the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Heraclitans start from a preconception common to all men, as do
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we also, and perhaps the other schools of philosophy likewise.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: If, however, they had attributed the origin of the statement
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that contradictory predicates are present in the same thing to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: any of the Sceptical teachings, as, for example, to the formula
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "Every thing is incomprehensible," or "I determine nothing," or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: any of the other similar ones, it may be that which they say
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: would follow; but since they start from that which is a common
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: experience, not only to us, but to other philosophers, and in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: life, why should one say that our school is a path to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: philosophy of Heraclitus more than any of the other schools of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: philosophy, or than life itself, as we all make use of the same
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: subject matter? On the other hand, the Sceptical School may not    212
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: only fail to help towards the knowledge of the philosophy of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Heraclitus, but may even hinder it! For the Sceptic attacks all
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the dogmas of Heraclitus as having been rashly given, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: opposes on the one hand the doctrine of conflagration, and on
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the other, the doctrine that contradictory predicates in reality
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: apply to the same thing, and in regard to every dogma of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Heraclitus he scorns his dogmatic rashness, and then, in the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: manner that I have before referred to, adduces the formulae "I
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: do not understand" and "I determine nothing," which conflict
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: with the Heraclitan doctrines. It is absurd to say that this
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: conflicting school is a path to the very sect with which it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: conflicts. It is then absurd to say that the Sceptical School is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: a path to the philosophy of Heraclitus.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXX.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _In what does the Sceptical School differ from the Philosophy
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of Democritus?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: The philosophy of Democritus is also said to have community        213
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: with Scepticism, because it seems to use the same matter that we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: do. For, from the fact that honey seems sweet to some and bitter
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to others, Democritus reasons, it is said, that honey is neither
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sweet nor bitter, and therefore he accords with the formula "No
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: more," which is a formula of the Sceptics. But the Sceptics and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the Democritans use the formula "No more" differently from each
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: other, for they emphasise the negation in the expression, but
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we, the not knowing whether both of the phenomena exist or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: neither one, and so we differ in this respect. The distinction,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: however, becomes most evident when Democritus says that            214
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: atoms and empty space are real, for by real he means existing in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: reality. Now, although he begins with the anomaly in phenomena,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: yet, since he says that atoms and empty space really exist, it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is superfluous, I think, even to say that he differs from us.
