text: CHAPTER XXXI.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _In what does Scepticism differ from the Cyrenaic Philosophy?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Some say that the Cyrenaic School is the same as the               215
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Sceptical, because that school also claims to comprehend only
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: conditions of mind. It differs, however, from it, because, while
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the former makes pleasure and the gentle motion of the flesh its
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: aim, we make [Greek: ataraxia] ours, and this is opposed to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: aim of their school. For whether pleasure is present or not,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: confusion awaits him who maintains that pleasure is an aim, as I
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: have shown in what I said about the aim. And then, in addition,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we suspend our judgment as far as the reasoning with regard to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: external objects is concerned, but the Cyrenaics pronounce the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: nature of these inscrutable.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXXII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _In what does Scepticism differ from the Philosophy of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Protagoras?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Protagoras makes man the measure of all things, of things          216
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that are that they are, and things that are not that they are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not, meaning by measure, criterion, and by things, events, that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is to say really, man is the criterion for all events, of things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that are that they are, and of things that are not that they are
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not. And for that reason he accepts only the phenomena that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: appear to each man, and thus he introduces relation. Therefore     217
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he seems to have community with the Pyrrhoneans. He differs,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: however, from them, and we shall see the difference after we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: have somewhat explained how things seemed to Protagoras. He
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: says, for example, that matter is fluid, and as it flows,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: additions are constantly made in the place of that which is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: carried away; the perceptions also are arranged anew and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: changed, according to the age and according to other conditions
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of the body. He says also, that the reasons of all phenomena       218
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are present in matter, so that matter can be all that it appears
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to be to all men as far as its power is concerned. Men, however,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: apprehend differently at different times, according to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: different conditions that they are in; for he that is in a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: natural condition will apprehend those qualities in matter that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: can appear to those who are in a natural condition, while on       219
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the contrary, those who are in an unnatural condition will
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: apprehend those qualities that can appear to the abnormal.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Furthermore, the same reasoning would hold true in regard to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: differences in age, to sleeping and waking, and each of the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: other different conditions. Therefore man becomes the criterion
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of things that are, for all things that appear to men exist for
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: men, and those things that do not appear to any one among men do
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: not exist. We see that he dogmatises in saying that matter is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: fluid, and also in saying that the reasons for all phenomena
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: have their foundation in matter, while these things are unknown,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and to us are things regarding which we suspend our judgment.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXXIII.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _In what does Scepticism differ from the Academic
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Philosophy?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Some say further that the Academic philosophy is the same as       220
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Scepticism, therefore it seems appropriate to me to treat of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that also. There have been, as the most say, three
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Academies--the most ancient one, that of Plato and his
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: followers; the second and middle one, that of Arcesilaus and his
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: followers, Arcesilaus being the pupil of Polemo; the third and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: new Academy, that of Carneades and Clitomachus and their
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: followers; some add also a fourth, that of Philo and Charmides,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and their followers; and some count even a fifth, that of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Antiochus and his followers. Beginning then from the old
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Academy, let us consider the difference between the schools of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: philosophy mentioned. Now some have said that Plato was a          221
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Dogmatic, others that he was a Sceptic, and others that he was
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in some things a Sceptic and in some things a Dogmatic. For in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the fencing dialogues, where Socrates is introduced as either
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: making sport of someone or contending against the Sophists,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Plato has, they say, a fencing and sceptical character, but he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is dogmatic when he expresses himself seriously, either through
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Socrates or Timaeus or any such person. In regard to those         222
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: who say that he is a Dogmatic, or a Dogmatic in some things and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: a Sceptic in others, it would be superfluous, it seems to me, to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: speak now, for they themselves grant that he is different from
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: us. The question as to whether he was really a Sceptic or not we
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: treat more fully in the Memoranda, but here we state briefly
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that according to Menodotus and Aenesidemus (for these
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: especially defended this position) Plato dogmatises when he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: expresses himself regarding ideas, and regarding the existence
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of Providence, and when he states that the virtuous life is more
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to be chosen than the one of vice. If he assents to these things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as true, he dogmatises; or even if he accepts them as more
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: probable than otherwise he departs from the sceptical character,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: since he gives a preference to one thing above another in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: trustworthiness or untrustworthiness; for how foreign this is to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: us is evident from what we have said before. Even if when he       223
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: performs mental gymnastics, as they say, he expresses some
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things sceptically, he is not because of this a Sceptic. For he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: who dogmatises about one thing, or, in short, gives preference
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to one mental image over another in trustworthiness or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: untrustworthiness in respect to anything that is unknown, is a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Dogmatic in character, as Timon shows by what he said of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Xenophanes. For after having praised Xenophanes in many            224
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things, and even after having dedicated his Satires to him, he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: made him mourn and say--
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "Would that I also might gain that mind profound,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Able to look both ways. In a treacherous path have
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: I been decoyed,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: And still in old age am with all wisdom unwed.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: For wherever I turned my view
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: All things were resolved into unity; all things, alway
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: From all sources drawn, were merged into nature the same."
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Timon calls him somewhat, but not entirely, free from
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: vanity, when he said--
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: "Xenophanes somewhat free from vanity, mocker of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Homeric deceit,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Far from men he conceived a god, on all sides equal,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Above pain, a being spiritualised, or intellect."
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: In saying that he was somewhat free from vanity, he meant that
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: he was in some things free from vanity. He called him a mocker
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of the Homeric deceit because he had scoffed at the deceit in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Homer. Xenophanes also dogmatised, contrary to the assumptions     225
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of other men, that all things are one, and that God is grown
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: together with all things, that He is spherical, insensible,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: unchangeable, and reasonable, whence the difference of
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Xenophanes from us is easily proved. In short, from what has
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: been said, it is evident that although Plato expresses doubt
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: about some things, so long as he has expressed himself in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: certain places in regard to the existence of unknown things, or
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as preferring some things to others in trustworthiness, he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: cannot be, it seems to me, a Sceptic. Those of the New Academy,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: although they say that all things are incomprehensible,            226
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: differ from the Sceptics, perhaps even in saying that all things
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are incomprehensible (for they assert decidedly in regard to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: this, but the Sceptic thinks it possible that some things may be
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: comprehended), but they differ evidently still further from us
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in their judgment of good and evil. For the Academicians say
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that there is such a thing as good and evil, not as we say it,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: but more with the conviction that that which they call good
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: exists than that it does not; and likewise in regard to the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: evil, while we do not say anything is good or evil with the
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: conviction that it is probably so, but we live our lives in an
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: unprejudiced way in order not to be inactive. Moreover, we say
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that our ideas are equal to each other in trustworthiness          227
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and untrustworthiness, as far as their nature goes, while they
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: say that some are probable and others improbable. They make a
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: difference also between the improbable ones, for they believe
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that some of them are only probable, others probable and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: undisputed, still others probable, undisputed, and tested. As
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: for example, when a coiled rope is lying in a somewhat dark
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: room, he who comes in suddenly gets only a probable idea of it,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and thinks that it is a serpent; but it appears to be a rope       228
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: to him who has looked carefully around, and found out that it
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: does not move, and that it is of such a color, and so on,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: according to an idea which is probable and undisputed. The
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: tested idea is like this: It is said that Hercules led Alcestis
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: after she was dead back again from Hades and showed her to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Admetus, and he received an idea that was probable and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: undisputed regarding Alcestis. As, however, he knew that she was
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: dead, his mind drew back from belief and inclined to disbelief.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Now those belonging to the New Academy prefer the idea which       229
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is probable and undisputed to the simply probable one. To both
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: of these, however, they prefer that which is probable,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: undisputed, and tested. If, however, both those of the Academy
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: and the Sceptics say that they believe certain things, there is
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: an evident difference between the two schools of philosophy even
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: in this; for "to believe" is used in a different sense,            230
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: meaning, on the one hand, not to resist, but simply to accept
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: without strong inclination and approval, as the child is said to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: believe the teacher; on the other hand, "to believe" is used to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: signify assenting to something with choice, and, as it were,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: with the sympathy that accompanies strong will, as the prodigal
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: follows the one who chooses to live a luxurious life. Therefore,
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: since Carneades, Clitomachus, and their followers say that they
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: are strongly inclined to believe that a thing is probable, and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we simply allow that it may be so without assent, we differ        231
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: from them, I think, in this way. We differ from the New Academy
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: likewise in things concerning the aim; for while the men who say
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that they govern themselves according to that School avail
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: themselves of the idea of the probable in life, we live
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: according to the laws and customs, and our natural feelings, in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: an unprejudiced way. We could say more regarding the distinction
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: between the two schools if we did not aim at brevity.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Nevertheless, Arcesilaus, who as we said was the leader and        232
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: chief of the Middle Academy, seems to me to have very much in
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: common with the Pyrrhonean teachings, so that his school and
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: ours are almost one. For neither does one find that he expressed
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: an opinion about the existence or non-existence of anything, nor
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: does he prefer one thing to another as regards trustworthiness
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: or untrustworthiness; he suspends his judgment regarding all
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: things, and the aim of his philosophy is [Greek: epoche], which
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is accompanied by [Greek: ataraxia], and this agrees with what
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: we have said. But he calls the particular instances of             233
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: [Greek: epoche] _bona_, and the particular instances of assent
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _mala_. The difference is that we say these things according to
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: what appears to us, and not affirmatively, while he says them as
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: if speaking of realities, that is, he says that [Greek: epoche]
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: is in itself good, and assent an evil. If we are to believe also
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: the things that are said about him, he appeared at first           234
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: sight to be a Pyrrhonean, but he was in truth a Dogmatic, for he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: used to test his companions by the method of doubt to see
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: whether they were gifted enough to take in Plato's dogmas, so
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: that he appeared to be a Sceptic, but at the same time he
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: communicated the doctrines of Plato to those of his companions
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: CHAPTER XXXIV.
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: _Is Empiricism in Medicine the same as Scepticism?_
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: Some say that the medical sect called Empiricism is the same       236
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

text: as Scepticism. Yet the fact must be recognised, that even if
title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
author: Patrick, Mary Mills

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism

title: Sextus Empiricus and Greek Scepticism
